Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2017 03:33PM Tbone23 wrote: At my last appointment 3 weeks ago, he said that he could see the swelling and the other changes and that he didn't think that they were a result of the cyst or the dilated duct.  He said the Cipro would clear it up if it was an infection, but other than that he needed to see the results of the MRI (which is scheduled for 7/21).   I haven't spoken to him about the subsequent changes since I know he wants the MRI results.   I am not a person that complains too often, but the continuing changes in the one breast are starting to wear me down.  It is great that they have this board so that people can ask questions and share experiences.  I am trying to make sure to use this board to educate myself on what to ask instead of using the information to diagnose myself.
Posts.Title: Solitary dilated duct and lymph node swelling Tbone23 MamaBee23

Posts.Content: Jul 27, 2017 02:39PM - edited Jul 27, 2017 05:09PM by Tbone23 DJMAMMO, Do you happen to know if a fibroadenoma that size and located centrally (which I think means beneath the nipple) cause an issue with the lympthatic drainage if it grew quickly?  I ask because in the timeframe between the mammogram and the MRI , I have developed a fluid like swelling beneath my right breast.   It is not on the breast but rather right underneath it on top of the ribs.  It has become tender to touch.  The doctor looked at it this week and said it was odd and he could see and feel it.  However he said he needed the ultrasound completed to verify if it was a fibroadenoma before he could do anything.  Thanks in advance
Posts.Title: Solitary dilated duct and lymph node swelling Tbone23 MamaBee23

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2017 05:59PM - edited Aug 2, 2017 06:04PM by Tbone23 DJ - I know you can't speak for other radiologists :), but why would they use the word irregular? They previously said that the mass in the right breast was oval and now they label it irregular? Also I know that taller than wide is concerning but how about as tall as wide? Also the ultrasound on the left a year ago and then again one month ago identitied only one simple cyst. Now it shows multiple cysts of varying complexities that have grown quite a bit. These cysts are in the breast that has remained swollen (not painful) for 3 months. Could the cysts be causing the swelling as they grow or the reverse (the breast inflammation is causing the cysts to swell)? The surgeon is reviewing the ultrasound results and I have made him aware of my desire to have the larger cyst drained and the one solid mass biopsied. The swelling on the left is uncomfortable but the fluid on the rib under the right breast is painful. The ultrasound tech saw the swelling and asked how long it had been that way (when I told her four weeks she seemed surprised but didn't ask any other questions).Hopefully he will call tomorrow with a recommendation.
Posts.Title: Solitary dilated duct and lymph node swelling Tbone23 MamaBee23

Posts.Content: Aug 7, 2017 11:49AM Tbone23 wrote: Update:  The BS said that the mass should be biopsied.  He said that it is likely a fibroadenoma but since the MRI said it was 1.3cm and oval and the Ultrasound said it was 1.6x1.6x.9cm and irregular he wants it biopsied to be safe.  He did say that the fact that it did not have substantial bloodflow was a good sign.    He is also going to give me referral to get the cysts on the left drained but he doesn't think that is what is causing the unilateral breast swelling and swollen area in the clavicle.  He said that the tissue in the underarm is what he believes is causing that.  I asked him how it was possible that all started immediately after a mammogram and he said he did not know. He said that there really was no explanation why it would remain swollen for over 3 months.  He did mention that if we are unable to reduce the swelling, removing that tissue is a possibility.
Posts.Title: Solitary dilated duct and lymph node swelling Tbone23 MamaBee23

Posts.Content: Jul 24, 2017 10:44AM Tbone23 wrote: The MRI report is complete and online but says it is not viewable until tomorrow at 11:30AM.  Has anyone else experienced a delay between the report being finalized and when you had access to it?   I guess the good news is that the report was ready several days earlier than originally expected (1 day vs the 3-5 days they quoted).  Now I will have to see if I can move up my appointment with the doctor.   The waiting is so hard.  I am not sure how all the terrific women on this Board manage the dreaded waiting period.

Posts.Content: Tbone23 wrote: I am 44 years old and was diagnosed over a year ago with a solitary mildly dilated duct directly under a palpable mass (that was not seen in mammogram). Went for subsequent annual mammogram and no follow-up was recommended. However one month after the mammogram, the lump is still palpable and the breast has become swollen, itchy and extremely sore (no discharge or rash). Made an appointment for a follow-up in 2 days but this morning I woke up and the lymph nodes under my armpit and on my clavical (on the same side as the lump) are extremely swollen and look almost fluid filled. I do not feel any hard masses within the lymph nodes under my armpit but they are really swollen . Has anyone had any experience with overnight swelling of lymph nodes? It seems to be swollen all the way down the side along by breast. How long does a duct remain dilated before I should become concerned Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Solitary dilated duct and lymph node swelling Tbone23 MamaBee23

I looked thru all the paperwork and it talks about bruising and swelling but nothing about a hard mass. Any recommendations on what to try to see if I can reduce the firmness?

Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2017 10:24AM Tbone23 wrote: So the saga continues.  The MRI results came back today as a BIRADS 0.   No mass was identified in the left breast (the swollen one) however a potential mass was identified on the right.  I met with the doctor today and he said that he has no idea why the breast has remained swollen for 2 1/2 months.  He did say that he noticed redness around the nipple and that the lymph nodes are now swollen.  However he said that he did not see any indications that it was cancer.  The results of the MRI are   FINDINGS: BACKGROUND ENHANCEMENT: There is moderate background fibroglandular enhancement in both breasts. RIGHT BREAST: There is a focal area of oval enhancement seen within the right breast centrally 5 cm from the nipple which measures 1.3 cm. This has smooth borders. There is progressive uptake on the curve characteristics. A focal benign-appearing cyst is seen posteriorly. This probably represents a fibroadenoma. This should be further evaluated with a second look ultrasound. This correlates with the area of rounded asymmetry seen with in the central right breast on the mammogram. Multiple cysts are seen scattered throughout the right breast.

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2017 07:09AM - edited Jun 13, 2017 07:12AM by Tbone23 I had two diagnostic mammograms and two ultrasounds a year ago but this one was a screening mammogram.  I did mention the lump to the tech and she said that they would look for changes.   As for the lymph nodes/glands, I noticed when I put my bra on that there appeared to be swelling directly under and adjacent to my armpit.  The swelling is still here today and it starts about 4" up my arm from my armpit and continues down until the bottom of my breast.  I have felt it for lumps and I can feel my gland plus maybe 1 or 2 hard lumps about the size of a almond or bean.  Other than that they just feel almost spongey.  The space directly above my clavicle is also swollen but no lumps that I can feel.  At first I was just thinking that she pulled something when she did the mammogram but the glands and the breast pain/itch have me a little more worried.
Posts.Title: Solitary dilated duct and lymph node swelling Tbone23 MamaBee23

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2017 07:20AM - edited Jun 13, 2017 07:26AM by Tbone23 U/S results Focused imaging was performed at 12 o'clock 2-4 cm from the nipple. Additionally, real-time imaging was performed of the entire left breast and real-time examination was performed of the contralateral subareolar right breast. There is a solitary mildly dilated duct at 12 o'clock corresponds to the clinically palpable abnormality. There are no additional prominent ducts noted within the left breast or in the contralateral right breast. Some debris is noted within the duct on real time as well as a few of the static images. MRI was recommended by breast surgeon but denied by insurance  There has been no discharge that I have noticed.

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2017 12:37PM Tbone23 wrote: update: Went to doctor and she recommended another ultrasound due to breast swelling and puffiness under arm (lymph nodes were not swollen). Ultrasound picked up a cyst in the upper quadrant of the breast (that has been there for 2 years). Radiologist said cyst is only slightly bigger and has more debris but he recommended no addtl testing. Doctor looked at images and immediately disagreed and sent me to breast surgeon (cyst has a sharp spiculated looking edge But only one side which looks like a tail). Breast continued to swell (increased a whole size) and nipple flattened out (maybe due to swelling?). Met with breast surgeon and he said maybe mastitis (haven't breastfed for over 15 years an no fever). He prescribed cipro and recommended MRI. MRI was approved and I am currently waiting for the 7th day so I can get the MRI. Since the appt with the breast surgeon the swelling has decreased sligntly in both the breast and the armpit . However the nipple is still flattened out and now there is a huge blue vein running to it which makes the bottom of the areola look blue in color. In addition the center of the nipple has a dark red/purplish dot and there are about 8 hair follicles directly beneath the areola that are huge and make that area look pitted.(maybe due to swelling?) Are there specific questions I should ask at the MRI? Should I be concerned over the nipple changes?

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2017 11:31AM - edited Aug 2, 2017 12:08PM by Tbone23 Here are the ultrasound findings:  CLINICAL INDICATION: MASS IN BREAST COMPARISON:  MRI bilateral breasts July 21, 2017. Left breast ultrasound June 20, 2017. TECHNIQUE:  Multiple real time gray scale images were obtained of the bilateral breasts in a survey fashion. FINDINGS: Right breast: In the retroareolar region of the right breast there is an oval hypoechoic lesion measuring 0.6 x 0.9 x 0.5 cm with posterior acoustic enhancement likely representing a cyst. Within the 9:00 position 4 to 5 cm from the nipple there is an irregular hypoechoic lesion measuring 1.6 x 1.6 x 0.9 cm without discernible vascular flow, likely corresponding to the enhancing lesion seen on prior breast MRI. Left breast: In the retroareolar region of the left breast there is an ovoid hypoechoic lesion likely representing a cyst measuring 1.1 x 0.4 x 0.9 cm without discernible flow. Adjacent to this, there is a bilobed cyst or cluster of cysts measuring collectively 0.9 x 0.4 x 0.5 cm. In the 2:00 position 6 cm from the nipple there is a hypoechoic irregular lesion measuring 0.9 x 1.0 x 0.6 cm without discernible vascular flow. This lesion was seen on prior ultrasound and measured 0.9 x 0.4 x 0.6 cm. Within the left axillary region within the area of tenderness there is a patch of hyperdense tissue measuring 4.4 x 1.0 x 3.6 cm with a neighboring vessel. IMPRESSION: 1.  Irregular hypoechoic lesion without discernible vascular flow within the right breast 9:00 position, likely corresponding to the enhancing lesion seen on prior breast MRI. Six-month follow-up with ultrasound is recommended to document stability. 2.  Multiple hypoechoic lesions within the breasts bilaterally, likely representing cysts of varying complexity. Bilateral breast ultrasound in 6 months is recommended to document stability. 3.  Patch of hyperdense tissue within the left axillary region in the area of tenderness without suspicious lesion identified. BI-RADS CATEGORY 3 - Probably Benign Finding(s); short interval follow-up suggested I am familiar with the fact that cysts are B9.  Should I be concerned with the fact that the previous ultrasound said the irregular lesion at the 2 o'clock position was just a simple cyst that measured .9 x .4 x .6 (ultrasound was only one month prior to this).  Now this report says that same are is an irregular hypoechoic lesion and the measurements changed from .9 x .4 x .6 cm to .9 x 1.0 x .06 cm?   Also what does the hyperdense tissue mean? Should I  be concerned with any of these results?

Posts.Content: Jul 24, 2017 04:50PM - edited Jul 24, 2017 04:55PM by Tbone23 I had a painful mammogram back on May 5th that caused my breast to be painful at first and then after a few days the pain went away but it started to swell.  It has remained swollen on that one side for over 2 1/2 months. So far there has been no cause identified (waited for a month to see if it was hormonal (it wasn't), had ultrasound to which was clear and tried antibiotics) I should have MRI test results back tomorrow.   I will let you know if there is anything identified on the MRI.   It is soo frustrating since before the Mammogram I was completely fine.
